newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chips fall after rally fades.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chips fall after rally fades.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks ended lower Thursday, surrendering strong early gains sparked by IBM's robust earnings, as the market was unable to shake off a jump in long-term interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.47 points to close at 6,792.25, having given back a jump of nearly 80 points in the first hour of trading.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,244 to 1,149 on moderately active volume of 485 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Market heavyweight International Business Machines Corp. leaped 11-5/8 to 154 after posting first-quarter profits late on Wednesday that beat expectations on Wall Street.
But lackluster earnings elsewhere and general investor caution weighed on the market, analysts said.
"There's not a lot of conviction out there," said Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Brean Murray & Co.
It was the Dow's second consecutive losing session after it soared 173 points on Tuesday, its second biggest daily point rise ever. The blue-chip index fell 21 points on Wednesday.
After losing almost 700 points in a month-long decline since closing at a record high of 7,085.16 on March 11, the Dow has recouped more than 400 points.
But analysts said Thursday's action was a sign the rebound might be running out of steam.
"There's a lot of investors who believe this rally is going to fizzle very quickly," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management.
Traders said they expected further caution heading into next week when financial markets will be fixated on reports that could indicate the near-term direction of interest rates.
Economic data due next week includes the first quarter's Employment Cost Index and a report on the April jobs report.
Rising interest rates in the Treasury market played a role in dampening enthusiasm for stocks Thursday.
The 30-year Treasury fell 17/32, or $5.31 on a $1,000 bond, raising its yield to 7.13 percent from 7.08 percent at Wednesday's close. The price and yield move in opposite directions.
With investors' focus turning from corporate earnings to interest rates, choppy moves in stocks were likely in coming weeks, market watchers said.
"I think the least likely thing would be for another major rally," said John McElroy, principal at 1838 Investment Advisors.
AlliedSignal Inc. fell 3-7/8 to 69-7/8 after it reported first quarter earnings. Analysts cited weakness in the company's chemicals and automotive units.
Procter & Gamble Co. fell 2-1/2 to 123 after it reported quarterly earnings and said its sales were clipped by unfavourable currency translation.
Compaq Computer Corp. rose 2-5/8 to 80-1/8 after the company said its board authorised a buyback of up to 25 million shares of its common stock.
Dow Chemical Co. added 2-1/8 to 81-7/8 after the company reported flat first quarter earnings but said it expects a strong second quarter.
Computer Associates International Inc. jumped 4-3/8 to 48-1/2 after the software company said its fourth quarter earnings will likely be better than Wall Street expected.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.96 to 1,228.10.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 2.46 points to 771.18. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.59 to 543.95.
The NYSE composite index of all listed common stocks fell 1.09 to 403.62. The average share was down 11 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,284.896, down 11.997 or 0.16 percent.
